title: Saying "Hello" to the World
subtitle: Children's initiative connects global communities through greetings

content.text: Across continents and oceans, children are bridging gaps and forming friendships with one simple word: "Hello." In an innovative project called the Global Greetings Campaign, young people from different nations are using creativity and collaboration to promote unity and understanding.

The campaign invites participants to design "Hello panels," colorful fabric squares that showcase greetings in their native languages along with unique illustrations symbolizing their cultural identity. From the bustling streets of Tokyo to the serene villages of Kenya, children are taking part in spreading messages of warmth and connection.

Last month, thousands of Hello panels arrived at a charming community hub in Illinois, USA, where they were transformed into a vibrant tapestry. CommuniCraft, a cooperative workshop in Springfield, Illinois, specializes in teaching sewing, knitting, and crafting to people of all ages.

Founded by siblings Marcia and Harold Pittman in 2005, CommuniCraft was conceived as a welcoming space where individuals could come together, learn new skills, and share creative projects. Over the years, the workshop has blossomed into a cherished hub for community-driven initiatives and artistic expression.

Marcia learned about the Global Greetings Campaign one sunny afternoon when her friend forwarded her an email about the initiative. Intrigued by the idea of using artistic creations to foster cultural understanding, she immediately wanted CommuniCraft to be part of it.

“Just saying 'hello' is such a universal and simple act, yet it carries enormous weight in connecting people,” Marcia explains. “By designing Hello panels, children are sharing parts of their lives, their languages, and their cultures with each other.”

In the email, Carla Graham, the spokesperson for the campaign, described the vision behind the project. “We encourage kids to think about how they say hello to the world and to celebrate that greeting by creating panels with recycled materials such as old jeans, T-shirts, or curtains,” Graham shared.

Carla also called for volunteers to help assemble the panels into collaborative artwork, and Marcia eagerly offered to host a sewing day at CommuniCraft. When she learned that over 4,000 panels had been collected from nations including Brazil, Italy, India, and Vietnam, Marcia knew this was an opportunity to unite her community for a global cause.

The response was overwhelmingly positive. Harold spread the news to the workshop's mailing list, reaching hundreds of crafting enthusiasts. As dozens signed up to participate, Harold was thrilled. “It's remarkable how something as simple as greetings has resonated so deeply with people,” he says.

Local schools quickly embraced the initiative. Teachers encouraged their students to design panels and showed them how greetings can connect individuals on a personal and cultural level. Eight-year-old Emma loved the experience of creating her panel. "I drew a big sun, because 'Hello' makes me feel like sunshine," she smiles. "I wrote 'Hola' too, because that's how you say hello in Spanish, and we learn Spanish at school!"

Meanwhile, ten-year-old Ravi designed his panel with the word “Namaste,” framed by images of hands folded in traditional Indian greeting. “I want people to see my panel and know about how special Namaste is. It means respect,” he explains.

At another school, twelve-year-old Tania included both English and her native Tagalog word for hello on her panel. “I drew a Filipino flag to show where I come from. Saying 'Kamusta' reminds me of my grandma back in Manila,” she shares.

Even very young participants joined in. Four-year-old Liam simply painted a hand waving, along with the word "Hi!" in his favorite color, green. His mother, Beth, was delighted to see him take part in the initiative. “It's so simple yet meaningful for children to show how they greet people in their own special way,” she says.

For some families, the campaign became both a bonding experience and an entry into the world of sewing and crafting. The Johnson family sat around their dining table one evening, designing their Hello panels together. “We learned greetings from other countries while making our panels,” nine-year-old Megan says excitedly. “I liked saying 'Bonjour' the best. It sounds fancy!”
Her younger brother, six-year-old Alex, was equally enthusiastic. “I want everyone to say 'Hello' nicely, so we can all be friends!” he exclaims.

Local volunteers found the experience of assembling the tapestry deeply moving. “The panels are so beautiful and unique — you see the world reflected in them,” said Angela Vaughn as she stitched together rows of greetings. “We keep swapping stories about how each panel represents someone's way of reaching out.”

Karen Adler, another volunteer, agreed: “It's amazing to see kids' creativity on display. Some are so proud of their designs, and others included fun messages like sparkly stickers or ribbons. You can tell they enjoyed putting their hearts into this project.”

Carla Graham firmly believes the Global Greetings Campaign empowers children in profound ways. “Whether they're saying 'Hello,' 'Salut,' or 'Ni Hao,' this project helps them realize that even small expressions of kindness can ripple across the world. It's about fostering understanding, respect, and hope,” she explains.

Looking ahead, Carla sees the campaign branching into new initiatives. “We'll continue to find ways to engage young people — maybe next time focusing on artistic exchanges like recipes or musical traditions. The goal is always to create connections that enrich lives,” she shares.

The finished tapestry, now adorned with over 4,000 Hello panels, was displayed in New York City's Central Park and London's Trafalgar Square during International Friendship Day celebrations. Children can still participate by visiting the Global Greetings Campaign website to create virtual panels.
Through the universal language of "Hello," kids everywhere are proving just how powerful a single word can be.
